pages.text: $(l:materials/Thorium)Thorium$(/l) dioxide (ThO2), also called $(l:materials/Thorium)thorium$(/l)(IV) oxide, is a crystalline solid, often white or yellow in color. Also known as thoria, it is produced mainly as a by-product of lanthanide and uranium production. Thorianite is the name of the mineralogical form of $(l:materials/Thorium)thorium$(/l) dioxide. It is moderately rare and crystallizes in an isometric system. The melting point of $(l:materials/Thorium)thorium$(/l) oxide is 3300 Â°C - the highest of all known oxides. Only a few

elements (including $(l:materials/Tungsten)tungsten$(/l) and $(l:materials/Carbon)carbon$(/l)) and a few compounds (including $(l:materials/Tantalum)tantalum$(/l) carbide) have higher melting points. All $(l:materials/Thorium)thorium$(/l) compounds are radioactive because there are no stable isotopes of $(l:materials/Thorium)thorium$(/l).
